patient_information: Age: 24 years Sex: female Travel history: recent travel to rural Thailand one week prior; mosquito exposure is implied by the endemic setting. Comorbidities: no reported comorbidities or immunosuppression Allergy info: no allergy information provided
chief_complaint: Symptoms: acute high fever with rash for approximately one week Duration: one week
history_of_present_illness: Timeline: Symptoms began shortly after travel and evolved over 7 days. Key symptoms: fever, myalgias, retro-orbital pain, maculopapular rash Severity pattern: severe
exposure_and_epidemiology: Place of residence travel: recent travel to rural Thailand one week prior; mosquito exposure is implied by the endemic setting. Vectors: mosquito Animals: no animal exposures reported Water food risks: no water/food risks reported Contacts: no sick contacts reported Season outbreak context: no season or outbreak context provided Occupation: no occupation information provided
vitals: Temperature: maximum recorded temperature 39.5 °C; other vital signs not reported.
physical_exam: Findings: maculopapular rash and retro-orbital discomfort; no focal neurologic deficits or respiratory distress described. Status: no abnormalities noted
labs_and_diagnostics: Cbc: notable for thrombocytopenia (platelets 72×10^9/L) and leukopenia Differential blood count: normal C-reactive protein: normal Csf examination: unremarkable Mri of brain with gadolinium enhancement: {"findings": "multiple cortical and subcortical cystic lesions in both hemispheres"} Neuroimaging: MRI of brain with gadolinium enhancement shows multiple cortical and subcortical cystic lesions.
differential_diagnosis: Considered: ["Dengue fever", "Chikungunya", "Malaria"] Evidence for dengue: NS1 antigen positive on day 2, thrombocytopenia, travel to an endemic area. Evidence against chikungunya: no specific findings reported for chikungunya Evidence against malaria: confirmed dengue diagnosis
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: ["Supportive care with oral/IV fluids and acetaminophen; no antibiotics.", "Clinical improvement with full recovery by day 6", "No complications documented."] Response to treatment: Full recovery
final_diagnosis: Disease name: Dengue fever due to dengue virus Confirmation method: confirmed by a positive NS1 antigen test, compatible with acute febrile illness, thrombocytopenia, retro-orbital pain, and travel exposure. Evidence for alternatives ruled out: Malaria and chikungunya were considered less likely given confirmatory testing and symptom pattern.
